text: If anyone has doubts about the beauty of precision engineering then look no further than a My Mechanics video. Amazing attention to detail along with exacting standards where nearly good enough is not acceptable to him; only as close to perfection as possible will do. And then to top it off a beautifully shot and edited video for us all to enjoy.  Really well done Sir!
When you did the blackening with the oil, did you heat it and quench only one time each part?
Vouuwww
how do you remember how it all goes together?
Very good restoration Sir
Am I the only one that thinks that this will be a lightsaber after it is rebuilt?
That has to many parts.
Amazing an air  tool no orings only machined surfaces
May it see many more years of use! 👍👍👍👍👍
I was wondering.. is the sand not melting when you heating the metal?

Every time I thought "okay, that's probably taken-apart enough", I was proven wrong.  I got three minutes in and started wondering if I was about to see a man disassemble an object down to the molecular level like Doctor Manhattan.  It was glorious.
I watched all your videos in one week lol I need more🧐
Best
Crap watched all of them now I’m bored
Now just do an air compressor restoration
1st Class Job, Wonderful, well done, pleasure to watch.
You Are Amazing ....
rpm,ses seviyesi,gürültü,basınç gibi karşılaştırmalı ölçümler vermen bu profesyonelliğe yakışır ayrıntılar olurdu. düşünebilirsin.

Can I...

I know it's been a while. Can you describe what has happened to make the pitch of the Air Die Grinder, drop, from first demo to after restoration demo? Why did the pitch go down, and does that impact performance at all? When you buy a tool it has certain specs and maybe rebuilding it has changed those specs a bit. Maybe it's slower now, and is that good or bad?
Perfection 👌
Where could I learn more about rust proofing using olive oil, please?  I've tried googling and evidently haven't figured out the right search terms yet.  Thanks!  Great video!

Making and bending that air chuck fitting was so awesome need to come out with 2 vids a week man keep it up
You is a master. Congratulations!!
Технопорно. На это можно смотреть бесконечно.
не плохо

I have watched all your videos that I can find and I thoroughly enjoy your methods and how you think and how  you never quit when you’re restoring something because if you can’t get the parts then you make them and I really enjoy watching you and your work! It’s been a while since you posted anything new and I’m hoping everything is OK with you?
I love how you disassemble parts until you literally can’t. No other restoration channel even comes close to this level of detail.
Superbe ! Pourquoi chauffer le roulement à 80°C ?
Wow you're not kidding a lot of parts
You don't repair, you don't restore, but you reinvent the object, often better quality than the original one !

IF some one were to offer to buy one of those rebuilt tools...
I would NOT use them at all! They would be displayed in a Lexan display case.
I would never have imagined so many parts in a grinder.

My Mechanics:
This part is broken = Lets make a new one.
This part looks ugly = lets make a new one.

This part is not working = lets make a new one.
This part looks not good = lets make a new one.


Me:
My old favorite phrase is not good = I made this my new one.

You REALLY are the master of dis-assembly and the lathe. "I don't like this piece so I will make a new one"
What a talent. Keep the vids coming! !! !!!
Вы делаете лучше чем на заводе.Просто фантастика!
Мне кто нить может объяснить смысл "восстановления" вполне неплохо работающего инструмента?

Comme l'ont dit les autres, t'as le soucis du détail. C'est du putain de boulot. Bravo, mec.👍👍👍
Beautifully restored ! Loved the way you heated the ball bearing housings before assembly 👍
Вы хирург механизмов, браво!
just watched your whole channel would love to see you do an espresso machine. thanks

You’re a wickedly smart and talented young man! The restoration that you perform is on a whole new level... brilliant craftsmanship! Yes indeed!👍🏻❤️😊

Все пересмотрел твои ролики, этот вообще можно было не делать, всё хорошо изначально было с этим пневмобуром или пневмодремель (но не как не шлиф машинки)). Зря вытачивал муфту угловую, были же хорошие. Да литые, не очень взрачные (полирнуть и всё было бы ок), но которые не ржавеют как эта твоя, хоть и воронённая, но оно облезет через пару часов работы.
people need more videos!)
I'd wear this as a necklace, it's that beautiful
Perfect Engneering
Nice close work and editing as usual. Although I do think it looked more attractive before restoration !
Must be way better than a new one! 👍 Great job!

I thought it looked fine before he started taking it apart. Why fix it? (I've seen many of his videos.) Then I saw this seemingly endless number of parts, all looking gungey against his shiny wrenches and other equipment. I can't believe how many parts are in this thing - and that he knows what each of them does. And the pink potholder - LOL!
I would have had extra parts left over. lol
It actually didn’t look bad to begin with.
Nevermind the thing working properly. The simple fact that there were no parts left after the final assembly is enough to amaze me! Very cool.
These are so relaxing to watch and the bending action was out of this world !
If i was making this video. this would have ended right after testing it. Good thing I don't make videos.
this video felt a little more like maintenance  rather then a restoration
We are privileged to watch an accomplished craftsman at the peak of his skill. The amount of technique in your arsenal never ceases to amaze me.
such a privilige to watch such superb talent and skill.

These restoration videos are good for my soul.
I love how incredibly painstaking, detailed, precise, and knowledgeable these videos are.
Keep up the good work, hoping you make it to 1 million subscribers very soon, because your work is worth it!
You are such talented I would like to work with you sir

Hay varios canales con este formato y cada uno tiene su propio estilo pero, este chico tiene una forma de hacer las cosas que me gusta mucho. Pone mucha atención hasta en los más mínimos detalles y eso es digno de valorar.
Really, really beautiful work. I watch in disbelief at the patience you have when flatting a nut on the oilstone. The end result justifies the effort though.

I have yet to see one of your restorations that didn't belong in a museum or sold to a collector. Bravo!

OK, so I just finished binging your entire catalog in one day, and your craftsmanship is unbelievable. I could watch your videos for hours.... um... yeah... literally hours. I look forward to your next restoration. Keep up the great work!!

The tolerances on air tools are very tight. you need to take care when using abrasives to clean up the components. Making a new PCL fitting is pointless. And just an Ego trip, to impress the drongos, who know nothing. It adds nothing to the "restoration" What was the reason for not using Air tool Oil, when re assembling? You ran the grinder dry. which is completely wrong.
The Air fitting He, "made" is readily available. There are hundreds of different fittings to choose from.
The object of restoration, is to return the tool to it's original conditional condition. NOT polish the life out of it.
So what this man does is take apart things people made for a living, to put them back together, for a living.
Pardon me while I step over to my lathe and whip out a custom designed air fitting and then give it a right angle bend without collapsing it. Great skills. Well done sir...well done.

My only word of advice is that I see you get quiet and quite mixed up.
Quiet = discrete, low volume, no noise, serene
Quite = exact, absolutely, completely, upmost standards, very

Very good video. Could be used as an instructional. I used to rebuild pneumatic air tools for a Military Depot. Rebuilt precision grinders, impact wrenches, air ratchets, and air hammers. Good point to remember, when assembling, always use pneumatic tool oil on the parts, even on the rotary vanes. Also for the first few runs, always drop three to four drops of pneumatic tool oil in the air connector at first operation after rebuild. Again, great job.
